S1566-7367(15)00009-6 10.1016/j.catcom.2015.01.001 Fig. 1 XRD pattern of TiO2 nanoflowers prepared with different amounts of CTAB: (C0) 0mmol, (C1) 1mmol, (C2) 2mmol, (C3) 3mmol, and (C4) 4mmol. Fig. 2 SEM images of TiO2 nanoflowers at different magnifications. Fig. 3 TEM images of TiO2 nanoflowers (C3) at different magnifications. Fig. 4 TEM images of TiO2 nanoflowers prepared by using various amounts of CTAB: (a) 0mmol, (b) 1mmol, (c) 2mmol, (d) 3mmol, and (e) 4mmol. Fig. 5 BET result of TiO2 nanoflower N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms (a) and pore size distribution curves (b) from BJH method. Fig. 6 Photodegradation of MB:(a) TiO2 nanoflowers prepared with various amounts of CTAB and Degussa P25, (b) TiO2 nanoflowers (C3) associated with different amounts of H2O2, and (c) the photodegradation plots of several cycles (for sample TiO2 +0.5ml H2O2). Short Communication Enhanced photocatalytic degradation of rutile/anatase TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers Haifeng Xu a b Guang Li a Guang Zhu b Kerong Zhu a Shaowei Jin a b ⁎ a School of Physics and Material Science, Anhui University, Hefei 230039, China School of Physics and Material Science Anhui University Hefei 230039 China b School of Mechanical and Electronic Engineering, Suzhou University, Suzhou 234000, China School of Mechanical and Electronic Engineering Suzhou University Suzhou 234000 China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Physics and Material Science, Anhui University, Hefei 230039, China. Rutile/anatase TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers were prepared via a facile one-step hydrothermal approach using titanium tetrachloride and urea as the raw materials, cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) as the template. The prepared TiO2 nanoflowers were characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM and BET analyses. The photocatalytic performance of the as-prepared TiO2 samples for methyl blue degradation under simulated solar light was investigated. TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers with mixed rutile/anatase phase (prepared with 3mmol CTAB) give the highest photocatalytic activity. In addition, TiO2 nanoflowers show excellent stability after 9cycles under the same conditions. These results suggested that the mixed phase anatase/rutile TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers have great potential for the future photodegradation of real dye waste water. Graphical abstract Keywords Nanoflowers Mixed phases Hydrothermal Photocatalysis 1 Introduction Drawn by its wide potential applications in photovoltaic devices, water splitting, environment cleanup, cosmetics, white pigments, and others, titanium oxide (TiO2) has been widely investigated and concerned [1–5]. These can be attributed to its specific optical, electric and catalytic properties aroused by their intrinsic electronic structure, crystal phase, assembly, surface properties and particle size [6]. In general, TiO2 exists in four phases of rutile, anatase, brookite, and TiO2 (B). Among them, rutile TiO2 shows the best stability even in the critical environment and the more efficient white light scattering, which attracts an extensive application in lithium ion batteries, dye-sensitized solar cells and paints [7,8]. In most cases, rutile TiO2 as a photocatalyst exhibits a lower photocatalytic activity than anatase phase [9]. Yet, in some cases the photocatalytic activity has been proved to be superior [10]. Generally, anatase TiO2 is deemed to the more active phase for photocatalysis due to its surface chemistry and potentially high conduction band edge energy [8]. However, the fast recombination of photo-generated electrons and holes results in low quantum efficiency. Previous reports have proved that building junctions and chemical potential gradients into the catalyst can efficiently separate the electrons and holes. For the mixed phase rutile/anatase TiO2 heterojunction, photo-generated electrons are assumed to transfer from anatase to rutile while from rutile to anatase for holes because of the higher conduction band edge of anatase than rutile [11]. Therefore, it results in an efficient spatial charge separation and hindering recombination of electron–hole pairs. Rutile TiO2, unlike anatase phase, is generally difficult to synthesize. Most methods for the synthesis of TiO2 produce the kinetically controlled structure at low temperature. In general, titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) is used as precursors for the synthesis of rutile TiO2 with the existence of surfactant, organic acids, or mineralizers [12]. Although some methods have been adopted to prepare mixed phase rutile/anatase TiO2 heterojunction, there are still few reports on one-step hydrothermal synthesis using TiCl4 as precursor have been present. Driven by these purposes, we design and prepared rutile/anatase TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers via a facile one-step hydrothermal treatment with the assistance of cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) as the template. To evaluate the photocatalytic activity of TiO2 nanoflowers, methyl blue (MB) in the aqueous solution was removed under the simulated solar light irradiation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of TiO2 nanoflowers In a typical synthesized procedure, various amounts of CTAB (0, 1, 2, 3, 4mmol) was dissolved in 35ml deionized water, and stirred until the solution was transparent. Then 1ml titanium tetrachloride (TiCl4) and 3mmol urea were successively added to the solution followed by stirring for 1h. Afterwards, the solution was transferred to a 50ml Teflon-line stainless steel autoclave and heated to 160°C for 12h. The produced white precipitate was filtered off, washed with absolute ethanol and deionized water for several times and finally dried in a vacuum at 60°C for 12h. The sample prepared with 3mmol CTAB (C3) was chosen to complete the experiment due to the most remarkable photocatalytic performance. 2.2 Characterization The as-synthesized sample was characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) equipped with monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406Å) at 36kV and 25mA. The morphologies were investigated by a scanning electron microscope (SEM; Hitachi S-4800, Japan) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area was determined by an ASAP 2010 nitrogen absorption isotherm apparatus. 2.3 Photocatalytic measurements Photocatalytic activity of TiO2 nanoflowers was estimated by the degradation of MB. In a 20ml MB aqueous solution (15mgl−1), 10mg TiO2 powders were dispersed in a beaker. As an irradiation source, 350W xenon lamp (XQ350W, Lansheng Electronic Co., Ltd., Shanghai, China) with a wavelength range of 250–390nm and visible light irradiation (λ≥400nm) was used in the experiment. The absorbance of the solution was recorded on a UV–vis absorption photometer (UV-3200S, MAPADA Analytic Apparatus Ltd. Inc., Shanghai, China) at 464nm wavelength. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Composition of TiO2 nanoflowers Fig. 1 shows the XRD pattern of TiO2 nanoflowers prepared with different amounts of CTAB (0mmol, 1mmol, 2mmol, 3mmol, 4mmol, marked as C0, C1, C2, C3, C4, respectively). All diffraction peaks can be indexed to rutile TiO2 (JCPDS card no. 21-1276) and anatase TiO2 (JCPDS card no. 21-1272). The diffraction peaks located at 2θ=27.3°, 36.0°, 41.3° and 54.6° could be ascribed to (110), (101), (111) and (211) planes for rutile TiO2, while the diffraction peaks at 2θ=25.6° and 48.5° could be assigned to (101) and (200) planes for anatase TiO2. The diffraction peaks well accord with rutile TiO2 (JCPDS card no. 21-1276), which indicates the good crystallinity of TiO2 nanoflowers. Obviously, the diffraction peaks intensity of anatase phase (101) plane increased with the increase of CTAB, which indicates the increase of anatase/rutile ratio. This suggests the generation of rutile/anatase TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers. 3.2 Morphology The morphologies of TiO2 nanoflowers (C3) were depicted by SEM (Fig. 2 ) and TEM (Fig. 3 ). SEM images present the average diameter of TiO2 nanoflowers are ca. 500nm, which can be further confirmed by the TEM images. Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of TiO2 nanoflowers at different magnifications. As shown in Fig. 3(a), it is obvious that the as-synthesized TiO2 comprises well-defined nanorods. Multiple TiO2 nanorods aggregate together to form a flower-like structure with an average diameter of ca. 500nm. However, TEM images at high magnification (Fig. 3b) indicate that TiO2 nanoflowers are not composed of nanorods alone. The TiO2 nanorods are decorated by some nanoparticles. Obviously, the diameter of nanorods is about 20nm, and the length is on the order of 200nm. HRTEM image (Fig. 3d) presents that the decorated TiO2 nanoparticles are anatase phase. The fringe spacing parallel is estimated to be 0.35nm, consistent with the d value of (101) lattice spacing of anatase phase (JCPDS card no. 21-1272). These proved the existence of anatase phase, corresponding to the XRD pattern. Fig. 3c and d also further confirms that the nanorods are rutile phase TiO2. The interplanar spacing are 0.32nm corresponding to (110) plane of rutile phase. The size and anatase/rutile ratio could be varied by changing the amount of CTAB. Fig. 4 shows the TEM images prepared with various amounts of CTAB. When prepared without CTAB, dispersive nanorods with the length of ca. 200nm were observed (Fig. 4a). For Fig. 4b–e, with the increase of CTAB, the nanorods aggregate together to form nanoflowers. Meanwhile, density variations of black and white indicate the increase of the nanocrystals covered on the nanorods' surfaces. The variations of anatase/rutile ratio result in the difference of photocatalytic performance. 3.3 BET analyses To further detected the mesoporous characteristic and measured the surface area, the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) analysis was recorded by Micromeritics ASAP 2020, as shown in Fig. 5 . According to the IUPAC nomenclature, the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms (Fig. 5a) corresponding to TiO2 nanoflowers (C3) were assigned to type-IV, which clearly evidenced the mesoporous network of TiO2 nanoflowers [13]. The BET surface area of TiO2 nanoflowers possesses a high value of 106.29m2/g, which contributes to the adsorption of dyes. The pore size distribution curves calculated from the adsorption branch of the N2 isotherm through the BJH method were depicted in Fig. 5b. For the curve, a sharp peak of 2nm and a wide peak of 10nm were observed, which indicates that the type of pore can be assigned to mesopores. 3.4 Photocatalytic performance The photocatalytic properties of the as-prepared TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers were tested on the degradation of MB aqueous solution. Fig. 6a gives the photocatalytic degradation plots of MB for samples prepared with various amounts of CTAB under simulated solar light irradiation. As a comparison, Degussa P25 was also investigated. After 120min of simulated solar light irradiation, 43% of MB still remains in the solution for Degussa P25. For C0, an approximate pure rutile phase, only 30% of MB is degraded in the solution, which is poor than Degussa P25 indicating the inferior photocatalytic activity. Along with the increase of CTAB, the anatase/rutile ratio increased which induces the photocatalytic activity's enhancement. This may ascribe the formation of junction between rutile and anatase phase TiO2. Due to the position of the conduction band edge of anatase which is higher than that of rutile, photo-generated electrons flow from anatase to rutile, while the holes flow from rutile to anatase oppositely, resulting in the effective electron–hole separation [11]. The sample C3 prepared with 3mmol CTAB gives the best photocatalytic performance. After 120min irradiation, 72% of MB were degraded, which is higher than C1 (42%), C2 (68%), and C4 (62%). For further enhancing the degradation efficiency of MB, hydrogen peroxide solution (H2O2, 30%, m/v) was added to the MB aqueous (chose C3 for the experiment) solution with magnetic stirring upon irradiation (Fig. 6b). Notably, the degradation rate of MB was increased in the TiO2/H2O2 system. The increased amount of H2O2 (0.1ml to 0.5ml) is favorable to the enhancement of degradation rate. However, 0.8 and 1.0ml of H2O2 provide the opposite effect and therefore result in a decrease of degradation rate. Hence, the system with 0.5ml H2O2 has shown the highest photodegradation rate, revealing that appropriate amount of H2O2 contributes to the photodegradation of MB under simulated solar light irradiation. In the TiO2/H2O2 system, photo induces TiO2 to generate conduction band electrons (e−) and valence band holes (h+) under simulated solar light irradiation (Eq. (1)). Under the appropriate conditions, the electrons and holes were captured by O2 or OH− to produce free radicals (O2 −, OH ) (Eqs. (2) and (3)). H2O2 can accept O2 − to regenerate O2 (Eq. (6)). In addition, H2O2 can capture electrons to decrease the charge recombination, which can lead to the enhancement of photodegradation rate (Eq. (7)). Fig. 6c shows the periodic photodegradation for TiO2 nanoflowers without H2O2 toward MB. The degradation ratio of MB remains 81% after 7cycles and 75% after 9cycles, indicating that TiO2 nanoflowers can be stable and durable in the MB solution. (1) rutile / anatase T i O 2 + h v → rutile / anatase T i O 2 e − + h + (2) e − + O 2 → O 2 • − (3) h + + O H − → O H • (4) O 2 • − + H 2 O → H O 2 • + O H − (5) H O 2 • + H 2 O → H 2 O 2 + O H • (6) H 2 O 2 + O 2 • − → O H − + O H • + O 2 (7) H 2 O 2 + e − → O H − + O H • . 4 Conclusions In summary, TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers were successfully prepared via a facile one-step hydrothermal method using CTAB as the template. TiO2 nanoflower prepared with 3mmol of CTAB exhibits the best photocatalytic activity toward MB. The photodegradation for TiO2 nanoflowers with H2O2 presents an enhanced photocatalytic activity, indicating that H2O2 plays an important role in the photodegradation of MB. coredata.dc:description: Rutile/anatase TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers were prepared via a facile one-step hydrothermal approach using titanium tetrachloride and urea as the raw materials, cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB) as the template. The prepared TiO2 nanoflowers were characterized by XRD, SEM, TEM and BET analyses. The photocatalytic performance of the as-prepared TiO2 samples for methyl blue degradation under simulated solar light was investigated. TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers with mixed rutile/anatase phase (prepared with 3mmol CTAB) give the highest photocatalytic activity. In addition, TiO2 nanoflowers show excellent stability after 9cycles under the same conditions. These results suggested that the mixed phase anatase/rutile TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers have great potential for the future photodegradation of real dye waste water.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced photocatalytic degradation of rutile/anatase TiO2 heterojunction nanoflowers
